item.title: What is the real hardness of glass?
item.description: Introduction The glass on your cell phone needs to be hard enough to withstand daily life: it shouldn’t be scratched by your keys in your pocket, and it shouldn’t dent when dropped from a couple feet. Regardless of how we manufacture glass in an attempt to make it the right hardness, we need a way to measure its hardness. Today, that’s mostly done by microindentation. A microindenter machine uses a small pyramid-shaped diamond to put a small dent in the surface of glass: Then, a person (usually an undergraduate researcher ☺) moves the microindenter’s reticle (two black lines) to either side of the indent, and records the distance given by the microindenter: If she does this with both diagonals, she can average the two lengths and calculate the roughly square area of the indent.

item.title: Arduino projects
item.description: Breathalyzer The motivation for this project was to put people in control of their safety: ideally, the user clips the Arduino onto his car’s sun visor, so it is nearby when he enters his car. It would prompt him to breathe into it when (for example) it’s late at night and displays a different LED color depending on his blood-alcohol content. Plus, this device is a lot cheaper than breathalyzers for sale today.

item.title: Nurse Alert
item.description: In hospitals today, patients only get one button with which to call their nurse. The nurse has no idea if the button was pressed by accident or if it’s a real emergency. Maybe the patient just has a question. Nurse Alert is an Android app. Each patient has a tablet and their nurse has a tablet. The patient uses our simple interface to select where they feel pain, if they need to go to the bathroom, or if they have a question.

item.title: 3D printing projects
item.description: Zu I invented “zu”, a 3D printed item to keep your earphones from tangling. It can hold any earphone size and fits in your pocket! Here’s an 8-second video to show you how zu works. Plus, zu is printed with quality ABS plastic and can withstand heavy use. I created zu at Y-Hack, a hackathon at Yale. I brought my 3D printer (Solidoodle 2) and spent the allotted 24 hours prototyping in SketchUp.
